qas.question: In what year did the Maratha states lose to the British East Company?
What was the name of the war lost by the Maratha states in 1818?
How long did the British east Indian Company rule last after the war?
What caused the British east Indian Company rule to end?

answers.text: the Indian rebellion of 1857 and consequent of the Government of India Act 1858
Singapore as a key trading post

context: The Maratha states, following the Anglo-Maratha wars, eventually lost to the British East India Company in <a0_0>1818<a0_0/> with <a1_0>the Third Anglo-Maratha War<a1_0/>. The rule lasted until <a2_0>1858<a2_0/>, when, after <a3_0>the Indian rebellion of 1857 and consequent of the Government of India Act 1858<a3_0/>, the British government assumed the task of directly administering India in the new British Raj. In 1819 Stamford Raffles established <a4_0>Singapore as a key trading post<a4_0/> for Britain in their rivalry with the Dutch. However, their rivalry cooled in 1824 when an Anglo-Dutch treaty demarcated their respective interests in Southeast Asia. From the 1850s onwards, the pace of colonization shifted to a significantly higher gear.
